title: In ASOIAF, can knights who have joined the Night's Watch knight other people? - Quora
tags: A Song of Ice and Fire (book series)

response.answer_text: I don’t see why they couldn’t. The Night’s Watch’s institutional oaths forbid holding land and titles, but knighthood as a title is not inherently tied to hereditary powers or the expectation of passing on a line, etc. The Watch also takes part in various aspects of Westerosi society; it employs maesters and septons, for instance. So I don’t think anything would legally or culturally prevent a knight from knighting other men on the Wall. If the practice doesn’t seem widespread despite the implicit acceptability of it, it’s probably a twofold issue: People who join the Night’s Watch these days are likelier to be northmen or men of low social standing. So fewer men arrive at the Wall who are already knights (though clearly there are exceptions, like Alliser Thorne) or who would participate in knighthood in the first place. If you want an idea of how rare knights are on the Wall anymore, period, Bowen Marsh appoints a senile old man, Ser Wynton Stout, to command Castle Black in his absence for no other reason than because Stout’s a knight, i.e. that’s the best/only available knight around at the time. (And yes, other knights would have gone north with Mormont and been killed, but still — there were no other knights at Castle Black at that point besides this guy.)While knighthood isn’t inherently tied to hereditary titles, it’s still seen as a “career-track” benchmark for men who are on their way to somewhere else: heirs who will take lordships or men who want to earn money on the tourney circuit or as mercenaries, for example, or men aiming to start their own house. There’s really nowhere to “go” once you’re in the Night’s Watch and any promotions there would be (to first ranger, for example) aren’t reliant on knighthood. It wouldn’t help rangers make inroads with or against the wildlings, either; wildlings don’t care if someone’s a knight and might even mock someone who is. So the practical utility of being knighted is essentially nil, and in that case, there’s much less reason to bestow it or to seek it out.

I think it's possible. I don't see a direct contradiction with the oath. Ser Aliser Thorne who despised Jon Snow, was still a knight. He and others may be stripped of Lordships, and such, but I don’t thnk they lose their status as a knight when they take the Black.  Ser Aliser Thorne and Jon Snow at Castle Black, the Wall.
